title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @ChrisHolzer
comment:
25:50 what you said there is almost tragic.
Back when BF3 was released most of the people who played BF1942/V/2/2142 were utterly dissapointed because the "CallOfDuty'fication" had finally reached Battlefield with BF3. (EA's CEO even said at E3 that BF3's goal is to destroy CoD)....

Guess what those who loved  BF1942/V/2/2142 said back then? _"Does BF really have to attract that other type of player to be successful?"_
So EA is just pushing it even further now with BF2042 and those who cherished BF3/4 now understand what we, the core Refractor Engine BAttlefield veterans felt when BF3 came out - which in fact DRAMATICALLY dumbed down the franchise and REDUCED the teamwork on publics.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @muntedewok
comment:
hmmmm clearly the performance issues are subjective and individual on this. The Beta was an absolute meme for performance however I finally decided to boot this up and see what's what. System is an I7 11700k @ 5.1Ghz, 32gb DDR4 @ 3600Mhz, RTX 3070 and m.2 NVMe SSD's. Monitor G5 Samsung Odyssey 34" 1440P. Graphics set to ultra w/ DLSS set to Balanced (RTX off because it's a meme in general) was averaging 120fps+ with monitor refresh rate locked at 144mhz. Dipped a few times to about 100fps but never experience any stuttering or tearing. The game itself still feels janky, I hate how the tanks feel to drive and the blimpishness of the choppers is hilarious (hitting them with tank shells is almost too easy). The class system is a complete and utter joke and seriously needs to get in the bin. Gameplay however actually feels smooth and a bit more solid from the beta. Hit reg "sound feedback" has been toned down from the beta which is good and the nerfed slide mechanic also a bonus. The severe lack of hardware (guns, attachments, rocket launchers etc) is most definitely noticeable, holy hell it feels bare-bones. The interface is dogshit and the colour scheme chosen is offensive, as you said, seriously, is that item checked or unchecked in the menu?! WHAT IS THIS!

Think this game will be going on the backburner for a while and I'll be sticking with my BC2 server and BF4 for the time being until this shit is fixed. It was a good distraction for a little while however they've got some SERIOUS work to do. This is the part where EA (and especially their execs and that dickhead who came across from Activision) need to take an extended vacation (like to a Siberian wasteland) and let DICE work it's magic on fixing this shit show (ALA BF4). However it'll be extremely hard to polish a turd.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @dreamforger7166
comment:
So far enjoying myself more in BF2024 than Halo infinity‚Ä¶ but that is more the big battlefield vs arena shooter, I do not like arena shooters.

I got steady fps, no bugs (yet), and overall enjoyable gameplay, as the guns feels much better than in Halo (no Bungie magic for this one).

When I got used to the graphical style, I finde it beautiful and atmopheric.
But they lack more specialists, uniforms, weapons and mods.
Portal mode can help with the last.

And tbh, I got the game for free, but I think the ultimate edition with seasonpass should cost no more than 50$‚Ä¶

So say the combat feels dated, with no lean or ‚Äúparkour‚Äù, probably, but I haven‚Äôt been spoiled by these features as my journey stopped around BF4.
So for me it is just a solid BF feel.
Would I recommend it? For my own experience yes.
For the paying price? Narh get it on a discount, it is too expensive, and DICE did skip a lot of QoL thing if one have played the newer BFs.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @YOGI-kb9tg
comment:
so far from what i have played my game has been ok and only disconnected with portal a few bugs which is inevitable at launch but im not a fan of the specialists they have just taken the specialist items from the other battlefield games like one of them is just a ammo box... like really you do realize the infinite rocket launchers and grenades now and the best one i have played so far is dozer you have a literal bullet/ explosive proof shield that two hits anyone. one major bug i have seen is hovercraft being able to go up buildings and the call in vehicles is a problem especially when they are being called in on top of skyscrapers. i have seen some of the bugs from angry joes review and i can see why the player hit box is so large is because you have characters like dozer who have large frames but instead of making different hit boxes for each specialist they have just taken dozers hit box and put it onto the slimmer characters.i enjoyed portal but its feeling really lacking for its options so we gotta wait to see if they add more weapons/maps or games into the mix

also when it comes to helicopters they are far from invincible if you have a stinger i have had more helicoper and jet kills than i have gun kills and the major problem i have seen with the new maps is they are so large you will tend to only be in one place so you dont have these massive all out battle but instead multiple smaller skirmishes at the different sectors and the occasional zerg of players steamrolling areas

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @espirite
comment: Hi Skill Up. I really like your presentation and the effort you put into your reviews. Even if i strongly disagree with your opinions on some of them they are still great to watch. I find Battlefield 2042 a very frustrating game to see torn apart by people because after putting in countless hours since EA launch.... after refunding and then re-buying... me and my friends love the game. Everyone i meet in game seems to enjoy it as well. Once everything starts to click it feels like on of the best and most spectacular entries into the series. Its interesting how the reddit crowd and youtube have decided to write the game off when everyone playing the game seems to be having a great time. As with all battlefield games its rough at launch and will no doubt continue to improve over time  but honestly what we have at launch is fantastic fun. As people learn the classes, weapons and maps the games are already feeling more and more like the Battlefield we know.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @JustMe-sn8kd
comment:
It's not even the bugs that detract from this, it's the core of the game that really kills it. If this game were called something other than BF maybe it'd be just fine, but what they've done with the movement and heroes especially makes it no longer a BF. I love the 128 player concept but the map design is terrible, full of marathons and no action between points, reduced to a few areas of conflict. The weapons really aren't anything to write home about (something BF was always known for), at least there's only 22 of them to be disappointed in. 

Anyone who thinks Portal is going to be either worth buying the game for or will save this game is kidding themselves. I turned off xplay and was left with only a handful of populated servers (that weren't farming) and only 1 was full. The rest had maybe a dozen or so people in them. Like rush? Hope you like those 2 maps from BC2 and are OK with playing them over and over. Like progression? That's not a thing in portal. 

All the guns in the main mode are locked behind levels, gone are the days of using a specific kit from a class and unlocking that way. Want to see what your squad is carrying? Nope, good luck getting them to type bac to you. No All chat so can't say anything to other team. Want to check score board? Nope, not in the game. Your squad suck and you wanna switch? Can't. At least we can super sprint (terrible)?

The new hero system has spawned lone wolf gameplay in a way I've not seen in this series yet. I've yet to have my squad stick together to go for an objective. As soon as they spawn they just go their own direction to do their own thing. I do get revived (when not bugged) by randos on the team so I guess that's nice. Only about 5 classes are played right now: the 2 medics, hacker guy, grapple hook dude, and now that people are getting lvl 35+ wallhack lady. The guy with shield had his shield disabled within the first few hours of launch. Oh, I guess people are using wingsuit squirlkin girl too sometimes. 

Overall this game isn't a love letter to BF fans going back to their roots, it's an unashamed cash grab from the uninitiated. The blatant copying of Apex/CoD mechanics and the new twitch shooter feeling go against everything that was BF. BF was set apart by pushing forward in a more strategic way and needing to work with your squad/team to get objectives done. Now it's just a bunch of lone wolves doing their own thing. 

I've not played HZ because I don't like battle royales (sorry, squad royales). This game is severely underwhelming at best. While it is playable (usually) it's just not worth it. Maybe at 75% off but it's a fraction of the game it should be. I would give it a 4 because it is playable but as a BF game it utterly fails. If you do play it (I suggest xbox game pass for $1/month for 10 hrs of ea play, or EA Play pro for $15 once [be sure to cancel it] so you don't gamble $60+) then you'll see how utterly devoid the game is and how surface deep everything is. A handfull of maps on a couple of game modes and a token portal mode they hoped would save their game. It's not good.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @AllinWhenPlaying
comment: In general this feels like a free to play Battlefield clone that tries to be Rainbow 6 Siege at the same time. Player animations, animation smoothness, number of bugs, "looks good on screenshots" feeling, idiotic classes rework, insane abilities (like the free wallhack...) It frustrates me to say this, but at this point BF5 (which I'm really not a fan of) feels more "battlefield". Shame. But at least we have gender diverse classes! Such win, much wow. After BF1 Dice/EA seems to be always close to the right priorities, but not quite there.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @Slaking_
comment: Honestly, this feels like a new series than a Battlefield sequel. The movement and general vibe of the game is off, Specialists don't gel well with the Battlefield formula, the UI looks weird. It's such a shame, because I think we were all expecting something like Battlefield 4 but with fixes to BF4's flaws. Less restrictive classes, making it harder to vehicle whore, making it easier to deal with KD farming vehicles. Sure, 2042 does have answers to these, but it also just feels like those changes came at the cost of the game's soul. Maybe they'll fix it, but to me it feels like some of these problems are too fundamental to 2042 to ever truly be fixed. There's still some fun to be had, but man... I was expecting better.

This will be a long lasting game and a game changer for future titles. They moved gaming into the future. Ironing out issues on a complex coding on this level needs have little patiance applied. Portal is great, I do worry ü§î they will get portal to work without lag or rubberbanding. Seems like a great feet to overcome. Not sure the complexity of such a system. Im ticked about some things. I just want to drop it for a year and come back when its finished. But, training how to use the variouse tools and ranking up will be my focus and working on how to play the massive maps and stradagies in the time being. Love the ability to practice weopons and vehicles on bots.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @thedavescloop
comment: After playing the beta, the swap between classes and specialists is the reason I am not getting it. For all the reasons mentioned. I think it destroys team play and balance in favor of immersion-breaking gimmicks that feel like they are stolen from Apex, Overwatch and CoD. It just feels silly and plays like a chaotic mess and that's no fun. I knew specialists existed but I didn't realize it replaced classes entirely until I picked up the beta. Personally, I would like specialists done away with entirely. But I realize with all the time put into coming up with them that won't happen. The next best thing is that they be like a battlefield pick up or some sort of point-earned call in. In either case only a limited number of people on a team could use a specialist at once, and once they die they lose it until they can earn it or find it again. Maybe that could actually happen, though I doubt it. But it's more likely than them disappearing entirely. In any event, I won't be buying this BF at launch which will be the first time since I started with the franchise. I'll play Hell Let Loose instead.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @Layman927
comment: Battlefield 2042 is a mess. I'm not happy to say it because I love battlefield. I played 2042 again today and whenever I start to have fun, the servers rubber band on and off for 5 minutes, you die and you can't get revived or redeploy, you lose ANOTHER breakthrough game as attackers because every map in that mode has an impossible meat-grinder flag. Every time I play it's just a net negative experience. Everybody says battlefield games peak a year or year and a half after launch, but why can't it just be GOOD NOW? It doesn't have to be perfect, but why can't it just be functionally playable, with decent gameplay flow AT LAUNCH? And a bunch of players still defend DICE after getting burned 3 times now with the launch of BF4, the entire life cycle of BF5, and now the launch of 2042. Sad.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @KungFuIsland
comment: I don't know what it up with the optimization on this game.  I'm getting 65-85 fps at 1440p (med/low with meshes set to high)  on the 1080ti/i7 9700 pairing and seeing people getting worse results with more powerful hardware.  All I can guess is the CPU performance isn't optimized and is bottlenecking more powerful GPUs that should be able to put out well over 100 fps at all times.  This was an issue with BF1 and V too for a while, but graphics hardware was more homogenous at the time.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @CloudyDeveloper
comment:
The performance claims genuinely confuse me. This is why:
My specs:
3090 FE
9900k (no OC)
32GB RAM DDR4 3200MHz CL16
1000W PSU
on a 2TB NVME

Game is being ran on a 5120x1440p monitor (odyssey G9), which means it's about 10% easier to run than 4k. It runs fantastic... On all max settings, RTX off (its an FPS, always off, only on for campaign games), DLSS set to "quality", I am getting 80-120FPS during gameplay and in fights (in all out warfare). That is better performance than most modern day games give in my experience.

EDIT: I will mention, I DO get a LARGE lag spike maybe once every 6 or so games that lasts 2 seconds, not a big deal, but should be mentioned

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @chriswyatt9869
comment:
Was gonna get it but from what I‚Äôve seen on streams and videos I‚Äôm not impressed. Maps don‚Äôt feel very good or well balanced for breakthrough (little cover) and are frankly too big for conquest, even with 120 players it feels empty. That‚Äôs if it is actually 120, it doesn‚Äôt seem to tell you and has a lot of bots. 

Along with few maps and very very few weapons available, absolutely laughable in comparison to other battlefields. Hit reg looks dodgy, movement feels more like cod, odd HUD and UI choices like why no scoreboard or death counter? Change squads?

Specialists are stupid and ruin immersion. With clear balancing issues and redundant choices. Should of stuck with classes. These specialists are clearly just a ploy to sell skins and a thinly veiled excuse for lack of a story mode in attempt to have characterisation told though the multiplayer, which rarely works and is lazy.
That‚Äôs not even including the sheer amount of bugs I‚Äôve seen. That being said portal has potential and with enough care from dice could be really good for the series going forward.
Yes I know it‚Äôs all well and good saying this when I haven‚Äôt even purchased the game, but I as a potential customer are entitled to researching the products before I buy. And my research and experience with the beta is telling me to not buy this game in its current state. Halo infinite multiplayer just dropped today and that‚Äôs free, to me that‚Äôs a better option to invest time in until this game is sorted

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @ChantingInTheDark
comment:
This was my experience.

I was really hoping this would be a return to form for Battlefield. It certainly looked that way in the build-up. I played the BETA, which was okay, but the full game just left me cold.

The Hourglass 'training level' you could play while it was still installing was the worst first experience they could have done. The level looked basic, even on Ultra is looked amateurish in design - nothing fun about it at all, they should have left that out, already soured my opinion right from the start.

Speaking of graphics, I didn't really see a huge visual quality difference between Ultra and low also, which gave me a whole 'ported from console' feel to the game, I wonder if they started with consoles first then ported it.

LOTS of missing settings / quality of life settings all over the place, it's like they just ignored all of the perfected workflows in previous titles.

LOTS of bugs, the worst being the hit marker registration, it's AWFUL.

Whole game has an unfinished feel to it. I know it is early in the game, but I can only comment on what they gave us.

Everything feels a little spongey and soft too, weapon animations, the speed at which you run, even down to menu transitions - time to get in-game, it feels like everything needs tightening up, it doesn't feel like Battlefield to me - it felt more like a console version of Battlefield that wants to be Call of Duty but can't outright copy them.

But there were many areas in the maps that felt so underwhelming to me, the designs were generic feeling, no genius map design for sure. It's hard to describe, but it feels like an OLD game, not a new one.

The weapon modding mechanism is INFURIATING to use, COD Warzone absolutely destroys 2042 in this regard.

Now let's talk about the 'game'. This whole Ex-Pats thing is just lame. While climate change is real, I don't want to be depressed in a game about it. I just don't care about this whole Ex-Pats story, I mean, what's the point if you're not going to have a single-player campaign about it? Just feels like it was written by some inexperienced Millennial or Gen-Z graduate doing their first game, it's, just, lame.

Many of the character models also looked amateur, nothing memorable about them at all, just generic. Their animations are comedic. Their don't feel like gritty battle hardened characters, most look more at home serving you in Starbucks.

And let's not talk about the cringey after game report comments they make, I felt embarrassed to be playing the game when that came up.

The weather effects (because it's Climate Change yo) are just a gimmick. I can see people seeking out Portal versions of their favorite maps with those turned off.

Speaking of Portal, this is possibly the best part of BF2042. It was fun re-playing the classic maps, this was the one redeeming feature of the release, but not enough for me to keep it.

I may take another look months down the road, see if they've improved any of this. But for now, this isn't a slick, brand new feeling AAA Battlefield title, it feels out of date already.

For reference, my rig:

i9-9900K | ASUS ROG Strix Z390-E MoBo | 32GB Corsair Vengeance LPX DDR4-2666 | EVGA RTX 2070 XC | ASUS ROG Strix XG279Q 144Hz Monitor

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @katieblackmore2004
comment:
What cracks me up about so many people, is the whole Pre order then bitch scenario.
Since as far back as Fallout..... games have launched broken.
Then it seemed with the trend of more powerful consoles and PC's, the ease with which people can pre order digital copies.... more and more...... and more morons pay HUNDREDS for a game, just to play it early, then cry like a bitch that it is broken.
Take Forza Horizon 5.
I love that game..... I waited and got it on Game Pass.
Yet, people paid over ¬£60 to get it early and what did they find? Constantly kicked from playing online....... still does it now.
Ghost Recon launched broken as hell..... Cyberpunk released broken as hell.
When the Series X and PS5 dropped last year, CoD released broken as hell and was bricking console's.
The new CoD Vanguard is a bloody mess.
Gaming, or the quality of games being made has gone down hill massively.
Yet you retards STILL get a sniff of a new title, and lose your minds.
You see a little more on the title and a Beta.... and you lose your minds again.
People make videos hyping up the game..... then people spend upwards of ¬£90 on an early access version of a game you know NOTHING ABOUT, then when it releases broken, you take to Twitter and YT crying about it???
With BF it is even worse! BF4's launch was a joke!!! Cast your minds back too the clusterf#@k that was BF4, and i am amazed it became the legendary game it is.
BF1 was an awful buggy mess, crashing PS4 Pro's PC's.... no sound, no hit markers.
BFV was just crap..... better now, but was bloody rancid.
Then BF2042......... it has gone and done a Cyberpunk, and people are shocked?
Either gamer's and streamers are thick as pig shit, or just gullible.
The industry will only change when you morons stop blindly Pre ordering games, parting with YOUR money and becoming 12 week Beta testers for the rest of us.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @joshuablanchette878
comment: This is a very fair & accurate review. As a hard core  BFBC2/BF3 and BF4 player ( i played but did not enjoy BF1 and BF5), would summarize this first week of pre-order/EA play as essentially a real beta test and we're seeing what i'd expect from a real beta. The official "beta" was really an early alpha test. I am enjoying the game quite a bit but admittedly I'm a big Battlefielder and I am also always playing with a 4 man squad of longtime friends & BF3/BF4 clan mates. THat means that i am still having fun amidst the myriad of issues. I am telling everyone i know that i'm enjoying the game but advising that they should hold off till things stabilize. Rubberbanding can get really bad at times during conquest matches. Sometimes we would spawn into maps with no kits available and no weapon attachments were unlocked. We also encountered matches where we were unable to deploy into the game. At least 2 times we selected breakthrough on the new maps but got thrown into portal matches (twice on Arica Harbor). the "deploy" selection options were a nightmare...my success rate for deploying either on a teammate or flag was 50%. They need to better highlight who you're spawning on. They need to disable the friends footsteps or tone them down. There is more. Fun game but lots to get worked, definitely not a launch purchase. If this is like Bf4, it'll take DICE about 6 months to get things ironed out and then it'll be a good purchase.

author: @Hughesburner
comment:
I played a few thousand hours of BF2 and 2142 back in the day. I played  two rounds of 2042 last night and was left wondering what I just played. It was a chaotic mess...giant map..just run around trying to shoot things. I felt like I was having to put entire clip into enemies to get any response. With all the players on my team, it just added more confusion as I felt everyone was doing their own thing. 
Graphics wise, playing on a R5 2600/1070ti/16gb, I had to play on medium to get a good framerate, at that everthing seemed like a blurry mess, there are games that are 5yrs old that look/run better.  Going to pass on this for now. So many other games to waste time on right now, maybe it will get more optimized. Hackers killed the BF2 community and pushed us into private servers, I hope they don't ruin this one.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @mss8550
comment:
The biggest issue with the game is that it is not exciting.  There is no heart pounding moment, there are no thrills, time ticking palm sweating moment.
Gun play feels  not engaging.
1: Audio Sounds very subdued and muddy.  This causes no directional information is communicated and feel of intense fight is gone.
Sharp bullets firing sound and painful bullets landing on target sounds are gone.  Wide war stage audio is not there.  All effects clips are recorded bit muddy. not good.
2: Game modes.  PUBG & Tarkov & R6 & Warzone have very intense thrill for survival: here in 2042 there is no engaging moment for survival.  thrill of chase for target nor struggle for survival is bit gone.  Free for all or Battle ROYAL or r6 type of mode may help
3: Character animations are not  detailed enough to present engaging  gun fight scene: running and dodging sliding jumping over and falling down to ground.  They look awkward compared to other shooters.
the above makes less involving & engaging shooter.  Maps are wide this  makes me feel of war not close q combat but when I face enemy shooter for CQB the above 3 makes the fight very bad
very disappointing for 100 dollars AAA  FPS

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @xuvial1391
comment: Battlefield 4 CTE was 7 years ago, and I cannot believe this is the product we've finally arrived at. The unintended stuff (bugs, performance issues, etc) isn't the deal breaker for me, because they'll fix that. What hurts my soul are all the countless ways BF2042 has regressed compared to past Battlefield titles. You can fill a BOOK with how many basic features we took for granted in past Battlefield games are straight-up absent in this game. The past 10+ years of community feedback and improvements through all the various Battlefield titles (UI, gunplay, map design, movement, HUD, squads, roles, etc) has all amounted to nothing. BF2042 is not a successor, it is a giant leap backwards full of regression and removal.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @olternaut
comment:
It may hurt in the short term, but I think the real smart move is to wait a year for DICE to iron out the bugs which seems to be the norm for them on every damn launch.  And by then the video card makers will have their next...next gen cards out which shouldn't have any problems running this game at 4k, max settings, at very high frame rates.  I think the 3000 nvidia series and the amd 6000 series just don't have enough juice to run these games at the levels needed.  Oh, and let's not forget current and next years CPUs.  Hopefully in a year the chip crisis will finally be over.

Although, bugs or not, DICE seems to have made some questionable design decisions which may affect the success of the game long term.  And that's especially true if a competitor comes out of left field and slams the market with a revolutionary first person shooter of some kind.

Well, I guess I got some time to upgrade my PC while they finish the game post-"launch". Most importantly it will give time to the community to create good game modes in Portal, and for the best ones to become popular. Really Portal is the "we dont know what we're doing, you do it instead" saving grace of the game.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @sni18per
comment:
considering how lackluster and empty the new COD is, and how few actual good shooters there are right now (cant think of any to be honest), i was almost 100% sure i would buy the new BF. However, after playing the beta for few hours, i started to doubt that they will be able to improve or fix the performance by launch. On my 2070super i was barely getting between 70-90 fps regardless of the settings preset (all on low or on ultra, very little difference) and fps would dip more during weather effects, explosions, foliage etc. I will buy the game at launch and refund it if the performance is still the same as it was in the beta.
I would gladly pay 60euros for a reskinned BF3 or BF4 with consistant 144+ frames and better hit regsitration and graphics.

author: @wildbushdog4741
comment: laggy, frame freezing, and the game crashed on an xbox series x. This pretty much sums up the game when it is working and you can log in. The assault rifles are underpowered or maybe I'm just used to realistic gun ballistic work in insurgency sandstorm. The game doesn't have a region filter option or an option to turn cross-play off in-game. The specialist classes imo are just a way to include females on the battleground, no offense females but on the real battlefield, ya don't see chicks running around with the infantry. I would prefer character customization instead of barely noticeable specialist classes. The game makes everyone a winner by only showing what you did well and does not display KD for yourself or anyone else in-game. Not to mention no story mode for a 60 dollar game and yeah I did buy the 100 edition in the hopes the game would have good content, work correctly. and maybe the DLC will be decent, maybe? Overall this is a lazy cookie-cutter game trying to keep pace with that other big-name seller CoD. I would rather see Arma ported to console than play this trash tbh.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @josuad6890
comment: Oh, the game might be CPU bottlenecked then? afaik, ryzen 3000 series generally don't have the best single core performance (which is NEEDED for games) compared to Intel's offering or AMD's own ryzen 5000 series. if DLSS don't lift the FPS, then the problem isn't that the 3090 isn't powerful enough, but the 3950x isn't powerful enough. DLSS works by lowering render resolution so the GPU can dish out more frames. but if the system is CPU limited, what happened is the GPU will just sit around idling, waiting for the CPU to send the next frame data to the GPU to render. the frame drops also support suspicion that it is CPU limited. Usually weak CPU affects the 1% lows HARD. Don't get me wrong, a 3950X ISN'T weak, but it is kinda "meh" for games.

While Battlefield cares about multi-threads a lot more than other games, after 12 thread, it still cares more about architecture and IPC and core clock speed rather than number of cores. title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @VandergriftMoefies
comment:
Another textbook example that trowing stuff like DLSS, Raytracing and other fancy stuff at a game doesn't make a game... a good one. Funny that we have this tech now to create almost anything we want yet game were so much better like 10 years ago. Also, this game doesn't feel ''next gen'' at all. I still think BF 1 and 5 look waaaaaay better than this, and I don't like the wide open areas. Just feels empty and like there is nothing to destroy. 

But Portal looks really promising and with BF Bad company 2 being my fav fps of all time, I hope to see more of that in the future. But what's up with all these undercooked games. Every game that gets released now gets good after like a year, but never on release day. This industry is f*cked.

comment: You can tell the game has some Apex/CoD'ish vibe to it. upper management liked the release of CoD, plus games trend with the specialists thing. therefore EA wants to attract players coming from other games to BF (that's a risky strategy, you might end up with players moving from BF to other fps games since BF lost it's core game style). The game distanced itself from the original and the simplicity of BF and it only kept the name. too many buttons to press each with different ability. I'm afraid the game might end like MoH.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @sainterasmus4545
comment:
I really like what you're saying about immersion not necessarily being linked to realism. That's also my problem with BF2042. I think the game would be a lot more immersive if they had cut out the whole "nopat" or expat thing and removed the specialists. Because it's a near future setting I don't mind stuff like the sentry turret, grapple gun and even the wallhack thing, but I hate that they are locked behind these ridiculous "specialists". 
It makes no sense to have a game mode with 128 players be occupied by a dozen specialists, it completely destroys any sense of immersion knowing that there is probably 30 Boris' running around on the battlefield, 18 Sundance's and so on. That should've been replaced with Russian, Chinese and American grunts. It's much easier to believe a bunch of Russian grunts in 2042 would be carrying sentry guns to the frontline, whilst American grunts are using hyper advanced scanners to detect infantry through walls. It would also be more immersive in my opinion, to get to decide the sex and outfit of my character:
I hate that if I want to use Sundance's wingsuit, I have to be this black woman wearing a beanie, or that if I wanna call in a resupply station, I have to look like a civilian with a backpack (seriously, Angel looks more like a guy working in IT than he does a soldier). 

I think that's my biggest issue as well, look at Halo Infinite, they let you customize your own Spartan that fits into the Halo universe, I want to do the same thing for Battlefield, I want to make a soldier that looks like he belongs in a warzone and way too many of the operators don't look like that, most of them don't even have a helmet. Irish is probably the closest one, Dozer is up there too but that gasmask is ridiculous, trust me, I work in a Chemical Biological Radiological Nuclear (CBRN) army unit, and fighting with a gasmask on is beyond difficult.  
I really miss the Battlefield 3 and especially 4's character models, they looked great and it was easy to tell if someone was a medic, engineer, support or recon way before you pressed the spotting button. More importantly, they looked like soldiers in an army, ready to fight in global conflict. Specialists looks like a teenager's idea of how they would go to war, "yeah, if I was SEAL team 6 I would've just used a wingsuit to fly right through the windows and killed Bin Laden with an SMG lol... What? Body armor? Helmets? I'm just gonna wear something tactical... like a black beanie!".

author: @rubble_sog_7989
comment:
Its fine on console, honeslty had more fun on it in a few days than I had in all my time on BF1 and BF5. Games really something special on console. Sucks that people just make such baseless titles that dont specify anything. The fanbase will deplete with people like this making videos even tho each battlefield has come out half baked and always blossomed into the beautiful game we love and enjoy. People who are battlefield exclusive and never branched out are probably going to struggle with the technicality but if these player were willing to be to be open minded maybe they would enjoy the game as much as I do. The operator system while annoying is something people should pretty easily adjust too and does little to take away from the experience.
+I understand the game doesnt perform well on PC but for the time being can't you just cap at 80fps and play, all I see in lobby chat is PC players flexing their PC's then proceeding to cry when it drops below 120 fps, in due time im sure you'll be able to reach these numbers again just dont play for a bit or make limitations.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @JJumper8888
comment: I pre-ordered it (yeah I'm one of those lunatics with a last bit of good will for EA/Dice throw rocks at me if you want to. I don't give a piss)and played it the whole day on Xbox Series S. My review performance was really good, had a server crash couple of times. Had some typical dice please moments after getting teleported across half of the map and back but that's it when it came to Bugs. Oh and I forgot that trying to change your ammotype makes your character do a super janky looking animation and you end up with your knife pulled out (Dice please again) But with the rest I have to agree with the review Dice has to deliver otherwise the Franchise is done. Plus they defo have to tweak the gunplay and ttk there are some pretty...wonky things going on in there. So conclusion for me is...I give Dice that one last shot, if the first year fixes the many issues like Specialists etc. They can maybe rescue the Franchise and I'll keep on playing and giving my money for it...but if they won't...I will say goodbye to Battlefield with one last heavyhearted salute and leave it for good. Guess that's how everybody should do it especially those who've been playing it for a long time like I do. Hope somebody can do something of value with my personal console review and cheers.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @f0rresty
comment:
I love Siege as a game, but when I launch Battlefield, I wanna play exactly that; classes, some teamwork, community-run servers which spawn their own little communities through their regular players... if I want operators or specialists or whatever other name you might find, I'm gonna go play Siege, which makes way better use of them.
Apart from all that, I'm still very skeptical towards some of the other balance aspects. A sniper that 1-hit bodyshots within 100m? Who thought that was a good idea? Armour plates for infantry to reduce damage? I don't think there's a single game in which a perk like that didn't screw gun balancing.
All that makes me kind of sad, because I really wanna play a Battlefield game again. But it just doesn't seem like the game for me at the moment. Also, hopefully they'll have fixed the performance issues for high-end hardware, if I finally get the game after replacing my rig with a much needed upgrade.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @nicobenji0248
comment:
I get that the game has performance issues. But at *Ultra* settings in all out war(128 players), weather effects, lots to render on the map, good graphics, chaos on top of chaos, and you're still hitting 100 fps isn't bad. 
I mean you can't compare the performance of this game to many others because there aren't many others like that.
Yes performance on the next gen consoles is much more stable but next gen consoles are running at like medium to low settings. 

Yes they most likely needed to delay the game just to optimize but it's not surprising that they had a hard time optimizing the game with how much it should stress everyone's systems with just the concept of 128 player breakthrough game mode alone at the visual fidelity it's at.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @ParagonFury
comment:
So I played the trial available on Xbox Series X, and I say; this needed to be a June/July 2022 release at the very least. 

Credit where credit is due; it performed WAY better than the Beta did, and was definitely more fun, at least for a bit. The maps other than Orbital were much better - I definitely enjoyed Manifest (the cargo container one) a good deal. That said, it still has MAJOR issues, and unlike Skillup, I'll come right out and say it - 2042 was DEFINITELY a Battle Royale with Hazard Zone as first, then adapted into a traditional Battlefield later when they realized it wasn't gonna work out.

Hazard Zone is completely skippable and should've just been scrapped, because Hunt and Tarkov do everything it is trying to do, but better and with better takes on the idea. 

But all the design decisions, from how maps flow, how buildings are grouped together on many maps, how they're so basic and bare, how destruction works, Specialists and the loss of the class system to even the weapon customization system all scream "BATTLE ROYALE IDEAS" because they all make sense there and feel like they belong there, not in a Battlefield game. And all these non-Battlefield elements leave the game feeling like a weird mix of Warzone and Blackout's 50v50 mode, not Battlefield.


But one thing I will say they did well above everything else; the weather. Not only does it look great, but goddamn do you FEEL it, especially if you're in the wrong place at the wrong time.

comment: I haven't played the full game yet (I've only played the beta) but I agree with a few of your points. I'm not going to go far left and say it is the worst game I have ever played and I'm not going to go far right and say it's incredible. I will say I had a lot of fun during the beta. My outlook, a game which has potential to be incredible but is a bit of a bumpy ride right now. But think about it when have we ever had a perfect Battlefield launch yeah never, and the greatest games in this franchise and some of the best fps games ever were broken as hell at launch (BF3, BF4). I agree with your point though, give it a few months and it will be a great game.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @travisdavis4922
comment: Huge battlefield fan. 4 was better. 2042 does have some good aspects but overall very disappointing. The lack of a campaign, specialists are dumb, fairly useless classes, every one has a defibrillator so no reason to be medic class, lack of guns, no peak/lean toggle, glitches, portal maps look good but don't hit the same as 4. Shooting/sniping doesn't hit the same feels just ok, seems like less destructible environment compared to 2, 3, and 4. Team chat doesn't work or there is none, these are just issues I have with the game I've waited years for and hoped would be up to par if not better than 4. Why they keep allowing you to see the person who kills you highlighted red through objects like they also did in 4 is beyond me. Kills immersion and is unrealistic and gives away your position. I'm disappointed. I'll still play since I bought it but why couldn't they make a battlefield without all the bs specialists, and the ability to lean around corners which 4 had..............God damn you ea for selling out with microtransactions and focusing more on that than creating an instant classic like 4 was

2)  As far as this years line up I‚Äôve played them all and it‚Äôs not even close but the thing I‚Äôm very skeptical about (Halo) is not only does the free to play worry me about the player base but how is the game going to play when your in a ranked game and you have PC xbox s, 1x, xss n xsx all in one lobby? 

3)  I recently bought Hunt: Showdown (on sale game + extras for  $17.99) by the time I learn the game I‚Äôm sure Battlefield will be in a good state so I‚Äôm not worried at all lol  @Skill up thanks for you bringing Hunt to my attention I am very late to the party but man is this game unique and enjoyable

Yep, I refunded my game already. This doesn't FEEL like Battlefield anymore. It feels like DICE's best attempt at slapping COD onto the old Battlefield's skeleton. It's janky, hollow, and poorly executed - especially on PC. I can't get past the specialists, the stupid specialist-centered animations, the overly massive maps, and the lack of traditional Battlefield features that drew many of us to the game in the past.

author: @RA9935
comment: The 128 player count and the bots are a huge reason as to why the performance is so bad. Coming from Planetside, Squad, and other high player count games, your rig/console has to render in every single player and bot in real time (since there is no pop in/out spotting) and when they fire a gun, die, use explosives, etc. In 50v50 games aka squad, my performance on a low end rig is pretty good until heavy firefights get underway, then I drop to the mid 40s for a bit. The beta had me at 40fps the entire time on the lowest settings.......

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @jordan-ramblinaround2323
comment: I got it too. Played it today on a Xbox one x all day (New Zealand location change) I do not like it. Specialists suck. As everyone said, getting rid of the class system was dumb. Comparing gameplay to battlefield 3 or 4, Or 1, it's a joke. Gunplay feels bad. Clunky, It's closer to pubG than battlefield or cod. Time to kill is really inconsistent. Worse than previous installments. It's like playing a bad version of Warzone. Maybe if all you've experienced is bf-V, you'll probably like this. Map design is disappointing too. The portal is a neat idea, but it needs a considerable amount of work too. Portal is what people will be playing within a few months when people quit playing the base 2042 game. I don't see this being a fan favorite like others. It also graphically isn't great on Xbox one. If you don't have one, I'd wait to get it when the Series X or PS5 is more available, if you dig consoles.  Right now, either way, on any platform, I'd pass on this. I can't believe im saying this, I'm a die hard battlefield guy. I've played all of them since BF 1942. but I had more FUN playing vanguard. And it's garbage. This ain't it, Chief.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @jacobcunningham6771
comment: Learned not learnt

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @ben7ani
comment: As a Battlefield veteran and having played 2042 for about 6 hrs from launch, I'm lost... There is no class identity anymore, anyone can do anything. I loved the unique identities in the Battlefield games (medic, recon, support and assault). Now you won't have a clue who is doing what and have to pray to the RNG gods that someone is carrying a medical kit or ammo crate in your assault team / squad. Portal is OK... it's great that you can play the old content again with new skins.... But its exactly that.... Recycled content with a new skin. Hopefully it will grow on me. The gunplay doesn't feel anywhere near as smooth as BF1 / BFV currently which is also a concern. However I am having fun.... But whether I sink hundreds of hours in like previous titles is yet to be seen.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @starkiller34
comment:
Here's what bugs me most about this
Dice have said that hazard zone was designed as a love letter to BF fans.... To me, an old BF fan, a love letter would be... the best conquest mode we've ever seen. That's what I don't get. BF's identity, the sole reason I want to play, is conquest. I want the maps, classes EVERYTHING to be balanced around conquest. The rest is fluff. And I think most old school BFs fans would agree. Which is why I'm puzzled that our 'love letter' is another game mode... that borrows surface elements from other games that aren't BF.  Portal seems like a much better love letter as well. 
I'm afraid they put a lot of effort (and unfortunately balance) into the least interesting part of the game.

As for performance.... I mean, if you pre-order a BF game after BF4 happened, you a lost cause. And the lack of console codes in a world where Cyberpunk happened is just terrifying. I hope things go great for the console peeps but shit smells bad.
... I cant believe I'm saying this, but Halo looks like the king of shooters this year... Does... does that make me an Xbox bro now? Do I start praising Spencer? Teach me bros.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @stefanrenn-jones9452
comment: double the fps with alder lake. Zen2  is notoriously bad in WZ. I benchmark a 3700x with a 3080 in a plethora of FPS games everyday for hours and map size and player count is the difference between 100 and 200fps. Bf2042 portal with 12 players on a tiny map will probably get you 200fps on your 3090 build at 4k dlss. 8700k will bottleneck anything a 3700x bottlenecks. 5600x and 10700k and higher to reduce bottlenecks from 50% down to about 25%. That is 25% lost performance due to map size, player count, pc system processes etc. The 10fps difference between systems is precisely due to the clock speed of the zen2 cores. This performance review is falsely premised on the GPU. Delving into deep misunderstanding lol

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @jibreelkeddo7030
comment:
The reason your performance is terrible is because BF2042 is CPU limited, not GPU limited. Player count has doubled over BFV, meaning that CPU stress is probably also doubled. That Dice managed to keep the performance downgrade (vs BFV) less than 50% already shows incredible optimization and cleverness.

Frostbite engine scales to 8 cores, but most important is high single thread performance. There is no CPU today fast enough singly threaded maintain over 100 FPS for BF2042. 

Intel 12600k or 12900k w/ low latency DDR5 will get you close but not all the way there. If you are a hardcore BF fan, upgrade your PC to Intel Raptorlake or AMD Zen 4 when it comes out ‚Äî Only then will you get the FPS you desire. This is not something that is really in Dice‚Äôs hands.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @trignite
comment: If DLSS Performance isn't helping framerate much then it just shows how your bottleneck is on the cpu/ram side more. The 3950x isn't actually that great for games with its 4+4 ccx and having two ccx's. The 5950x destroys it in gaming with a single 8+8 ccx layout reducing latency. Even a 5600x is faster than the 3950x. Alderlake has much better ST performance, so if this game has bad multithreading then alderlake is going to perform a lot better. Also Nvidia's gameready driver isn't out for the game and will probably come out at launch so I would expect better performance from that as well.

author: @resentfusion5634
comment:
hardline was the most fun bf but personally bf1 was my most enjoyed pvp experience since it felt so grounded not only as a battlefield game but in reality only downside i remember was tanks were literally too strong which seems to translate itself to helis in the 2042 game. idk what identity they are going for but this doesnt seem to be it but im not the only gamer so ig time will tell.
the audio reminds me of tarkov gameplay but somehow worse that clip really showed me. if thats AAA game comp standards im honestly flabbergasted.

games are demanding more and more and often giving less and less its nice that battlefield might cater to lower end but i have a 1060 super and i5 and cant run the beta and anything more than that isnt mid end IMO. also this sucks for anyone with a top of the line pc which shouldnt make sense if their are issues with a machine of higher capabilities than optimize and delay till its good to go will be rough if they push this game with all these issues but taking the NW release into consideration i have little faith. love how i can think a game isnt fun yet i can still enjoy your reviews great vids glhf

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @Sako0944
comment:
No console review codes means last gen consoles is a shit show, and they should have never put any resources into making it compatible with that outdated hardware. Battlefield was in a dire need of a refresh and this next gen hardware was a good opportunity for them to go big with the level of detail / scale. They can't even get the game to run well for the release on modern hardware so I have zero hope for last gen stuff. 

What is with every studio wanting to just push out a product that is unfinished? Not only do they hurt sales for their product but they also hurt future releases from their studios and publishers because it sets a bad track record / precedent. What happened to game studios knowing the target audience for a game and just focusing on delivering a solid product for them? Everything needs to be pumped out at lightning speed now adays and must appeal to as wide of an audience as possible. 

Drop last gen support and focus on current hardware that just came out that people will be using for the next 4-5 years. And actually release the game when it is in a finished state....

comment: Performance sounds more bound to CPU than GPU if you are having less performance issues on lower player count servers, or server bound CPU load; would have been nice to see some HWInfo data, could quickly check CPU and GPU load to see where the bottleneck is. Particularly given you had issues on a 3950X, it would be interesting to see performance at lower resolutions on a 5Ghz 9900K or something, possibly even DRAM buffer/latency issues? I sort of hope it's some performance limitation designed to run protected process threads and curb cheating issues on PC, it would explain a little bit why console performance is otherwise totally fine, super weird you can't brute force it on PC.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @rebornkusabi7264
comment:
Honestly, this is a me-thing, but this game was immediately marked as a lost cause once gameplay came out of the tornado in action. Tornadoes are not fluffy clouds of air- it's a sheer, nightmarish, well, "Finger of God" (His middle finger specifically). Even for a gameplay stance, just have a destructive instant-death tornado on the field could have opened up so many cool atmospheric gaming moments of being stuck in a building while it's passing through, being in a gun fight, and seeing it just annihilate anyone outside too stupid to know those things are death incarnate.

As is, based on footage, it's just a dumb turbo booster and air lifter. A tornado of that ferocity can turn a plastic straw into a razerblade. And if this thing was in Fortnite, I wouldn't be so hard on it. But it's in Battlefield, a series known for it's (to a varying degree granted) level of realism, and it just takes me out of the experience seeing a bunch of realistically modeled idiots hang-gliding around a funnel cloud.

author: @biggrav
comment: I really hope that portal mode becomes battlefield's version of custom games, and in that regard I feel like the specialists and their abilities could be a good thing, adding to the sandbox and expanding what kind of cool game modes you can make. I'm hoping battlefield manages to fix it's bugs and find its place in time, but also hope that it takes long enough for halo to establish itself as the king of FPS once again. I want both to be good, I just want halo to be relevant again :')

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @WeinerTouchy
comment:
On a note for performance - it may suck but lower end hardware being prioritized right now for a PC game makes sense. Look at the market right now. You CAN'T buy 20xx cards anymore at retail since Nvidia stopped producing them. You CAN'T buy a 30xx series card since... reportedly... Nvidia has stopped production right now BUT EVEN IF THEY DIDN'T you still can't buy one. 

The only way to get a new card is to pay $2,000+ to a scalper or Newegg. No one is going to do that. 

What can you buy right now? 10xx cards. 1650 Supers are ALL OVER THE PLACE right now in retail stores, and for a lot of people those are actually an upgrade vs what they had before. 

In a normal market - performance would be a priority on the newest hardware because people would be able to buy it. We can't right now - so what's the point in making that the priority? Just so a reviewer can say "Well on my 3090 it ran at 300fps!" That's unrealistic performance that 0.0001% of players are going to have. 

Also - All Out War mode will for sure be the worst performing of all the modes and that shouldn't be a shocker to anyone. When Battlefield moved to larger servers for consoles and unlocked the framerate we saw performance bumps for sure, but the framerate was inconsistent and bad to play. 

PC players are now getting that short end of the stick. DICE makes a really great visual engine and they are constatnly pushing Frostbite to spit out some of the best graphics that we have today. They are at the same time however forgetting to optimize that engine for the one thing their games are known for - large scale battles. 

Whats the point in having this photo realistic fidelity levels for the game when it runs like absolute dog water.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @ex0stasis72
comment:
This tells me that this game is worth a temporary 1-month EA Play subscription, but not $60 until after those design changes happen.
Edit (11/13): Ok I underestimated how bad the performance would be on my PC. 100% CPU usage with a 4-core i5 7600K. GPU and RAM are fairly well optimized, but this game was keeping all 4 of my cores at 100% making it very hard to aim with it stuttering every second or two. I would say that it was unplayable if not for the fact that it seemed like everyone else was also experiencing their own performance issues (that or they were just bad players). There's $15 wasted for EA Play Pro. I'm uninstalling, and I'll try it again in 6-12 months.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @jinx20001
comment:
i think your performance problems say a lot about whats going on, when DLSS does barely anything for your framerate and lowering settings also does nothing much its pretty clear that the issue is not GPU its CPU and yes a 3950 should be more than good enough but i suspect the 5000 series aswell as the intel 10/11/12 series should help alleviate that issue somewhat with far better per core performance, ray tracing also demands more CPU power so with it struggling so much already on the CPU side adding ray tracing likely just made it worse. pretty clear when DLSS isn't helping that the issue is CPU related. i hate to be that guy but the 3000 series AMD processors are not really top of the line, they have latency issues and single core performance deficits that were massively improved with the 5000 series, the amount of cores just wont make a difference. the example of others with issues you showed aswell was a strong indication of CPU issues, 8700k is even lower single core performance than the 3950x... i know it sounds stupid that a 3950x isn't top of the line but the reality is it isn't.

moral of the story with that seems to be the game is very cpu heavy and that makes a lot of sense, 128 players/AI and everything going on its hardly too surprising but its also on them to recommend the correct hardware because clearly a recommendation of a 2700x isn't in the ball park.

i can say for sure at high/medium settings at 4k using a 5900x/3080/32gb 3733 ram on the beta i was getting around 70fps, sometimes higher sometimes lower, no DLSS because it wasn't available and no RT ofcourse.

the other issue with the game which you didn't mention is the beta was locked in DX12 mode... notoriously shit in battlefield 1 and V and often using DX11 improved frame timing massively and thus the experience... was this available in the release build of 2042? did you use it?

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @itsme123126
comment:
i played the beta on medium/high on a ryzen 5 2600x and Radeon rx 580 8 gb and on 1080p i got anywhere between 40 and 100 fps depending where i was, it was really horrible, turning everything on down didnt do anything except reduce vram usage, which didnt mean anything since game never used over 5gb of vram anyway. 
My friend on an RTX 3050 and Ryzen 5000 series laptop struggled to get 45 50 fps on low 1080p and he had around 10 15 fps on high/ultra. It was literally unplayable for him.

It really turned us off from ever wanting to buy and play this game. For comparison we run Forza Horizon 5 on stable 60 fps on mixed medium-ultra settings and i ran Metro Exodus on ultra on the 580

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @JustS0meK1dd
comment: Thanks for the video dude. Just a bit of info on performance... the reason that DLSS doesn't help your FPS much is because you are already CPU bottlenecked the majority of the time at 1440p (due to terrible optimisation of the large match types and the 3090 being an awesome GPU). Using AI to reduce the render resolution and scale it up again doesn't offer much more performance because your CPU can only feed frames to your GPU so quickly. You will see much more difference in 4k, but even there the 3090 is bottlenecked by the 5950x in combat a lot of the time.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @Left4Coragem
comment:
Can't really aproove of this game. Sure there's the portal mode, but that's it, it's just a side mode. The game was clearly intended to steer into the specialists/heroes and abandon what the series was always about.

The 128 players also did nothing for me. You are put into maps too big to have any frontline and without classes and squads it just becomes free for all with teams. Many times people accuse call of duty of never changing, but they don't change too much because they found a formula that works well for that series. Battlefield 2042 is like the awkward call of duty, that wants to be sci fi with super powers, but that's not what the audience of that series is looking for.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @RockSolitude
comment:
Nah, the game design of BF2042 is still a cash grab. Specialists and takedown animations WILL be monetized and the overall design of BF2042 is still meant to cash in on the CoD Warzone crowd, but Ripple Effect had an idea with Battlefield Portal and EA/Dice allowed its inclusion to throw the Battlefield vets and fanbase a bone, because there'd be more outcry against the game if it wasn't. 

Vote with your wallet. Keep buying this stuff this is what EA/Dice will keep serving, and the Battlefield franchise will get even more distorted from here. You just KNOW there's gonna be a ton of DLC and bonuses for this. Don't buy it at all or wait a year or a few years and get it on discount with all the DLC and bonuses included. BF2042 is mediocre at best and as a Battlefield title it falls short.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @siubhan2047
comment: We are at an impasse with AAA games like these.  Eight years ago I bought an AMD 7950 OC, which at the time was one of the fastest GPUs you could buy.  Something today that is only slightly faster costs TWICE as much (inflation adjusted).  Moreover, a comparable card with regards to "performance bracket" costs SIX times as much.  Hell, the GPU costs more than the rest of the PC combined (in the case of a 3090 more than double the price of the rest of the PC).  I want to ask, who are these people actually able to afford 3090s, that struggle to perform in a game like this no less?  I am convinced the average gamer is definately not able to.  Actually I am glad I got off the AAA train, since there are many many indie games with fresh mechanics, gorgeous artstyles and devs that are passionate about what they made.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @JonathanDavidsonn
comment:
Some critical points to make about your review:
The lack of performance goodness over the GPU change is because the game is now bottle necked by CPU instead of GPU. This has been known since the beta and this is one of the major challenges they're having to optimise currently. Your graphics card wouldn't boost performance as much as a good CPU. It's hard to explain, but a 3950X is the same CPU I have in my computer (GTX 1080ti + 3950X), and it performed significantly better than my laptop (+10FPS extra). (5600H + 3060) although these two systems should be almost mirrored in performance, minus the extra features the 3060 can offer to make the game run faster (DLSS). 

The rendering of the game may be being held back due to the restraints of the systems made by the CPU. My sussy thoughts is that the system which is trying to stream a buffer of data to the GPU, the CPU trying it's best to process the memory from the RAM and sending it to the GPU and such. I dooon't think the game utilises direct memory access on PC, which is why we're getting this terrible performance because it's trying to replicate that method of sending data to the GPU which is causing it.

I think the best performance improvement is comparing it to a higher spec CPU mainly rather than the GPU. I haven't done that much research into it however.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @lvx969
comment: So the thing about Portal Mode... You can only use the logic editor in Team Death Match and Free-For-All which means you can't full customize weapons & gadget loadouts in Conquest/Conquest Large or Rush game modes. Classes are restricted to only have access to the gear that is available in that classes base game. This means Battlefield 3 classes can only use Battlefield 3 weapons and gear. The only way to circumvent this is with the logic editor which can't be used on Objective based game modes. This was done intentionally to restrict players from making custom games that compete with the default 2042 All Out Warfare mode.

author: @thedofflin
comment: EA made a major blunder, they were disappointed that a lot of people don't really play the World War period titles, so they decided to return to the modern period BUT also tried to reinvent the game at the same time rather than just delivering a solid sequel to BF4. They were too scared to double down on the BF3/BF4 formula that was a major hit. Whoever convinced management to allow Portal to be developed is a god damn hero because this game would've likely flopped without it.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @WinnieBlue
comment:
Hey Ralph, just a quick comment on performance.
Whilst it looks like BF2042 isn't terribly well optimized, your low performance numbers may be attributed to your CPU. The Ryzen 3000 series is great but is no longer the latest and best, and may struggle with this game at lower resolutions such as 1440 low settings or with DLSS. I am curious if you went to 4K on your 3090 if you'd get similar FPS (70-80) due to a potential CPU bottleneck.

Still, I have a R9 3900x & RTX 3800 so your performance report was super useful for me. Thanks as always!

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @thedofflin
comment:
Portal is literally the only thing to save this game. It fixes:
- removal of classes
- poor performance with large player count
- pointless AI players
- competitive imbalance
- bad 2042 maps (if there are any, sounds like Orbital is trash)

In Portal you can:
- use normal class system
- improve performance by reducing player count
- remove stupid AI players
- make custom competitive modes with sensible rulesets
- avoid playing 2042 maps

The reason why your framerate on Low and Ultra is mostly the same and DLSS not doing anything is because you were CPU bound.

Games are starting to become even more CPU heavy these days, most for seemingly no real reason, and as a result the GPU you have doesn't really matter after a certain point unless you also have the best CPUs.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @gameboyterrorysta6307
comment:
I loved BF2 (against bots), BF2142, BC2, BF1 and BF3. BFV was "set of great ideas executed terribly" and was just "enjoyable" after many patches. I wouldn't call it good game tho. BF4 is one of the most overrated games I've played. It was good but it wasn't "peak BF" as many claim it was. 

BF2042 beta was huge dissapointment, especially as it ran awfully and threw away almost everything previous Battlefields brought to the franchise. Everything was half-assed for sake of being different from predecessors. Sad cost of this decision: it was different than what we've seen in previous games but there was nothing original, just inferior copies of other games.


I have no hope for BF2042. This "review in progress" only made me more convinced that I will not buy this game yet. However I am much more optimistic then I was after beta. I would consider it if performance+audio is fixed or when portal gets BF2143.

BTW: 2080Ti is still very high-end part. Especially when we take into consideration how much more powerful it is than consoles' GPUs and how expensive it is.
BF1 was fully functional on release, performance was great, so was audio.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @boozebeard9501
comment: You should have looked into the CPU more in regards to performance. Pretty much any time a game involves a lot of players or AI entities you can guarantee it is going to be more CPU intensive than usual (MMOs are notoriously CPU heavy). The fact changing settings that are mostly gonna impact GPU performance didn't do much, that you saw better performance on the lower player game modes and that people on older systems still had good performance (Older CPUs tend to hold up better than GPUS) all point to a CPU bottle neck.

They were for sure designed with hazard zone in mind (which turns this very similar to any other hero shooter rolaye), and they might even work as a concept there. But it makes absolutely no fucking sense having the same 10 characters bein picked over and over and over across a fucking 128 players mode, lol. That said, I kinda like the freedom of not having classes. Is so dumb to have someone running at you for knowing you only have a sniper rifle cause your character is wearing a balaclava. They should've made some fucking generic soldier skin alternative and opened every specialist skill for picking when putting together a class...

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @evanwiger
comment:
Servers play a big role in getting a good frame rate with these big maps in an early release form. Things will be ironed out in about a year, that's just my guess. The future of video games, or at least multiplayer AAA games are just betas or even Delta's and Alpha's. BF is my jam. still gonna play it. still gonna enjoy (what I can as of now). Nvidia noted that the drivers are more or less the same as the beta drivers. in a couple months id expect some improvements. We're playing AAA games that are still in major development. If you have the mindset that the game doesn't come out till June or even august or next year. Good for you, I cannot. 

EDIT: Audio is one of the most important aspects of BF. I'd imagine servers and frostbite has a hard time in early access to get everything synced up. Im drunk, I'm going to bed.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @incediumignis
comment: It seems to me, and from my testing on the beta that bf 2042 is EXTREMELY bound to cpu performance, it doesnt matter if you have a 1080ti or a 3090. If you dont have latest and greatest cpus you will not notice a difference, and i bet you that if you enable graphs and performance metrics if you compare your 2080 ti and 3090 with the same cpu at lets say 1080p, you will get identical performance and both gpus being under utilized. Thats why in hazard zone you get better performance, less players less stuff to calculate more cpu power to drive your frames. In my case during the beta with a 5600x and a 2070 super i got 90 ~110 fps consistenly.

title: So far, I do not recommend: Battlefield 2042 (Review In-Progress)
author: @kyleb1958
comment:
The beta was terrible, gun play felt really off in particular the bullet drop/velocity. Advanced movement and specialists really don't belong in the battlefield formula, made this feel more like a apex legends clone than a battlefield game. I had high hopes, sure portal looks great but it seems like damage control so they can still get away with selling specialists as microtransactions but I'm sure they won't stop with just specialist. It's a pity a secondary mode is what people are most interested in, if dice focused more on what the community actually wanted from a new battlefield title imagine how much better this could have been.

Meanwhile Halo is looking better and better.
